They invest thousands into it, expecting sales teams to magically become more productiveâ€¦ and instead, reps spend more time updating Salesforce than actually selling.

Itâ€™s no wonder salespeople have started calling it â€œSpreadsheet 2.0.â€
So, whatâ€™s going wrong? A lot. But here are the biggest issuesâ€”and how to fix them:

 1. Your CRM shouldnâ€™t be a time-sucking black hole.
Most CRMs are just cluttered with outdated deals, duplicate contacts, and â€œ90% likely to closeâ€ opportunitiesâ€¦ from three years ago. Reps donâ€™t trust the data because updating Salesforce feels like more work than closing the deal itself.

 2. Distributors arenâ€™t updating your CRMâ€”stop expecting them to.
Manufacturers love assuming distributors will track deals in Salesforce like an in-house sales team. They wonâ€™t. They never will.

 3. Forecasting shouldnâ€™t feel like a voodoo ritual.
If your sales forecasting is just people guessing numbers leadership wants to hear, youâ€™re basically flipping a coin.

 4. If quoting still takes days, youâ€™re losing deals.
A shocking number of manufacturers still use manual quoting, spreadsheets, and price lists from 2019. If your customers have to wait days for a quote, guess what? Theyâ€™re already talking to your competitors.

 5. Salesforce isnâ€™t a sales strategy.
If your sales process is brokenâ€”chasing low-intent leads, manually handling repeat orders, relying on email for pricingâ€”Salesforce wonâ€™t magically fix it. Itâ€™s just a tool.

 Bottom line? Salesforce can be a game-changerâ€”but only if you actually build a sales process that works. Otherwise, youâ€™re just throwing money at an overpriced to-do list.

postsData.content:
Do We Really Believe in a Meritocracy?

We all love the idea of a true meritocracyâ€”where the best performers rise, where hard work and talent determine success. But hereâ€™s the real question:

 Are you in an environment that actually rewards results?
 Are you personally pushing yourself to grow, develop, and earn your place at the top?
 Do you truly want to do the hard work to thrive in a meritocracyâ€”or just the parts that feel comfortable?

A real meritocracy isnâ€™t about waiting for recognitionâ€”itâ€™s about delivering undeniable results. The best ideas win, the strongest performers move up, and those who embrace accountability excel.

So, be honestâ€”are you in a system that rewards results? And if not, are you ready to create one for yourself?

comments.commentText:
Yes! I could go on about this forever Lucas Wilson. I would add this to your already convincing argument. How does the system you are in assess merit? Though this isn't where you were going, the only problem, as I see it, with the current shift to hiring and promoting exclusively by merit is that we don't know who's defining merit...

Does merit mean you work the hardest? That you have the best ideas? That you're the CEO's nephew? Until you know the answer to that question, merit is a game of hit and miss. It's on leaders to clearly define the rules of the game and then live by them.

postsData.commentAdded: Great points! True meritocracy demands accountability and continuous growth. Lets create environments that celebrate performance and results!

postsData.content:
7 Mindset Reframes Of A High-Performer

(To rewire your brain for success). 

Talking about having a growth mindset is trendy.
Embodying it is life-changing.

It can change the outcomes of personal and professional goals.

Reframing your mindset is one way to get started.

High performers know that this simple practice can:

ï¸ Help you achieve your dreams.
ï¸ Improve your mental health.
ï¸ Increase productivity.

If you want to change your outlook today,
Start with these 7 mental reframes:

1. Reframe failure so that every setback is set up.
 "Iâ€™m afraid of making mistakes."
 "Mistakes are proof Iâ€™m learning."

2. Reframe pressure so high stakes can lead to high growth.
 "I canâ€™t handle this pressure."
 "I perform well under pressure because I prepare."

3. Reframe challenges as opportunities.
 "This is too hard."
 "This is a challenge I can figure out."

4. Reframe discipline as the key to success.
 "I donâ€™t feel like doing it."
 "I do whatâ€™s necessary, not just whatâ€™s easy."

5. Reframe time and prioritise.
 "I donâ€™t have enough time."
 "I make time for what matters most."

6. Reframe success as a habit.
 "I hope this works out."
 "Iâ€™ll make this work through action and persistence."

7. Reframe opportunities as action steps.
 "Iâ€™ll wait for the right time."
 "The best time to start is now."

When you change your approach, you change your worldview.

This starts with how you choose to speak to yourself.

Seeing the bigger picture is a good exercise,
But reframing it is where real growth happens.

Which reframe is your favourite?
Let me know below â¬‡ï¸

* * * * * * *

If you liked this post, you may like my newsletter: The Growth Mindset.



Repost this to help your network & follow mefor more content like this.

postsData.content:
You need to follow the rules and do as youâ€™re f*ckn told!


Thereâ€™s a process that was created, and you need to fall in line.

Abide by it or else.

For years, these are the things I heard from managers of mine.

â€œKainatsky, you donâ€™t listen, just follow our process.â€œ

They were right, I sucked at listening to people just because of their title.

I saw the broken processes and didnâ€™t blindly align with them.

And to my own detriment, had to call it out.

In my heart and soul, I always knew I just couldnâ€™t work for someone

who I didnâ€™t respect and looked up to.

I couldnâ€™t follow processes that were unchecked.

I verified, then trusted.

So I bent the rules, and operated in the grey areas.

Over the first few years of my career, no one was having it, and it cost me.

But then I figured out who I wanted to be and how to become him.

And you know what?

It required saying f*ck your rules and kicking down some doors.

Within 4 years, I went from an entry level job to the c suite.

I quadrupled my salary and bolstered the self belief

that had been battered, bruised and abused for my very short career.

Do not be scared to challenge authority and convention.

Most of it is designed to keep you on their desired path, not yours.

Not all rules and policies are built to make you successful.

Have the courage to ask questions and walk away when necessary.

I didnâ€™t succeed into my great career, I failed out of the shitty one.

Yours truthfully,

Exposing the industry. 


The more I'm talking to people the more I realize that people aren't educated on how good Ai Agents are.

Solar companies are sitting on tons of unclaimed money and it's their own fault.

This is no way a slam on the industry.

This is a way we can help many customers!!

Every company has unfinished accounts. This means customers have solar equipment on their home they can't use.

The loan companies are not paying the solar companies all of their commissions meaning solar companies literally have hundreds of thousands up to millions of unclaimed money!

This has been an ongoing industry issue for 5+ years it's nothing new anybody who's worked anywhere in solar for a week knows this.

There are tons of meetings on how to schedule more efficiently, and get more accounts fully installed.

THE REALITY.

You need more electricians in the field. Just a fact. You need electricians to go button up the homes and fix electrical fixes and just do things at homes that need to be done to satisfy customers!

THE PROBLEM

Solar companies don't want to pay electricians. They are the most expensive field cost.

There is a never ending cycle for solar companies. They need corporate people to answer the phone of angry customers.

So they hire more people for the phones.

Taking the budget away from hiring the solution to the actual problem so no electricians are hired!

Keeping you in the death loop of not being able to collect the rest of your money, and having angry customers.

THE LOOP

Executive says go collect the M3 payments
"were are sitting on hundreds of thousands we need to collect in Q4"

Managers say ok we can do but it takes our electricians away from installs
"can we hire an electrician"
Executive
"yea after we collect the M3 payments we'll have the budget for it."

THE SOLUTION
Take money from corporate ops team, put it into the field!

What's the first area you can cut without losing produciton?

You can't cut cad, permitting or PTO processors then the business doesn't move.

So you cut customer support and then you anger everyone of your customers. Then your reps complain and everything is downhill from there.

USE AI SUPPORT AGENTS!

You won't believe how good they are
They are way cheaper than you think
They can handle any conversation YES CONVERSATION you need.

Comment AGENT lets turn your company around!

Jamie Chapman
postsData.content:
Have you ever tried to start a fire in the rain while camping?

When I was ten, I had this grand vision of being the kind of kid who could survive in the wild. My hippie mother loved living off the land, being with nature, and cooking over an open flame.

I had watched her countless timesâ€”crouched over a tiny pile of sticks, lighting her Bic lighter until, like magic, flames appeared.

I was ready to try it on my own.

Of course, at age ten, your brain doesn't consider that rain might impact your mission.

I had damp twigs, a matchbook I stole from her friend's pack of Marlborough Light cigarettes, and the unshakable confidence of a child who had seen something done but never done it themselves.

I stacked everything into what I thought looked like a proper fire, struck a match, and watched it hiss out instantly.

Tried again. Same thing.

By the fifth match, frustration turned into desperation. I crouched there, flicking match after match, expecting some grand eruption of flames, but all I got was wet smoke and the realization that I had no idea what I was doing.

Then, my mom joined me. She saw the mess I was makingâ€”the scattered burnt-out matches, the sad little pile of damp sticks. And, instead of laughing, she knelt beside me and said:

"You're trying to start a bonfire before you've got an ember."

Then she showed me.

A single dry leaf. One match. Let it catch. Protect it. Feed it gently.

Within minutes, that one tiny ember turned into a small flame. The twigs caught, and the fire grew.

And I'll never forget what she said next:

"The trick isn't making fire. It's keeping it alive."

Decades later, I've realized that this is exactly how consistency works for entrepreneurs trying to build a business on their own.

Most creative entrepreneurs think they need to come out swingingâ€”posting daily, executing flawlessly, and running at full speed from the start. But that's like striking match after match without giving the fire a chance to catch.

It doesn't work.

Read more in the Weekly MindSweep No. 161 | Mind Your Business |
postsData.commentAdded: Love this analogy! Building a business is all about nurturing that initial spark into sustainable growth. Thanks for sharing such valuable insights!

Ever watched waves crash against the shore? What if I told you those waves could power your home? Meet the brand that's turning this floating idea into reality... 

Most of our energy comes from fossil fuels.

Which is the primary source of the climate crisis.

There are sustainable alternatives to these.

Such as wind, solar, and geothermal energy.

Which most of us have heard about.

But thereâ€™s a new entrant in this group.

Known as onshore wave energy.

is leveraging this.

Through its patented & cost-efficient technology.

That turns ocean and sea waves into electricity.

Hereâ€™s how it works (a little technical):

 The floaters move up and down with the waves.
 They move the piston that contains a hydraulic fluid.
 The hydraulic fluid then gets compressed.
 This compressed hydraulic fluid is stored in an accumulator.
 The accumulator releases this fluid to a motor.
 The motor moves the generator & electricity is generated.
 The hydraulic fluid moves back and the process continues

The system can even detect a storm.

In which case it takes a break.

And waits for the storm to pass

postsData.name:
Doug Lotierzo
Doug Lotierzo
postsData.content:
"You can't teach drive." "You can't teach effort." 

I hear this often when talking with leaders and managers about their people.

My response (somewhat tongue and cheek) is "Really? Well then where did you learn it?"

I've never gotten a response like "No where, I just always had it in me." There's always someone or something like parents, former mentors, coaches, books etc. that most people can tie their ambition to.

So if your people are struggling with this, don't fall victim to the 'you have it or you don't mentality.'

For drive, help them find their why and motivation for doing what they do on a daily basis. Connect what they do to what they truly want out of life.

For hard work, train habits. Look at how they manage their calendar, time, and task list. Spend time with them to show them where they are half-assing it.

You can't change everyone, but you can try before assuming they don't have the intangibles you are looking for.

comments.commentText:
"Can't" is used interchangeably with "I can't"

Turns out, it has nothing to do with us, or how easy/hard it is. It just means they can't, that's all

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Helping individuals discover their why can truly unlock their potential. We all benefit from guidance and mentorship! #Leadership

â†³ A deep one-on-one conversation beats
a hundred surface-level interactions.


3ï¸âƒ£ â€œStop overthinking everything.â€

Deep thinking is not a flaw.
It is your advantage.

Introverts catch what others miss,
see problems before they happen,
and make sharper decisions.

 It is not about overthinking.
 It is about thinking ahead.


4ï¸âƒ£ â€œTalk more to show confidence.â€

Confidence is not about saying more.
It is about saying what matters. 

Introverts do not fill space.
They bring clarity. 


5ï¸âƒ£ â€œBe more outgoing.â€

Presence is not measured by how many rooms you walk into.

Introverts show up where it counts.

They do not need to be everywhere.
Just in the right places.


6ï¸âƒ£ â€œPut yourself out there more.â€

Not all visibility is good visibility. 

Introverts do not chase the spotlight.

They let their work, ideas, and impact do the talking.


7ï¸âƒ£ â€œFake it till you make it.â€

Nothing to fake. ï¸

Introverts lead with depth,
not pretense.

8ï¸âƒ£ â€œIf you want to lead, you have to be visible.â€

â†’ strategy, and

9ï¸âƒ£ â€œBe more social at work to get ahead.â€

 Not about being social.

Introverts build strong networks through depth,
not constant interaction.


 â€œStep into the spotlight more.â€

The spotlight is optional.

Introverts lead, influence, and create impact.
Often from behind the scenes.

They are not looking for attention.
They are looking to make a difference.


 Ignoring bad advice is not playing it safe.

Introverts do not need to change who they are to succeed.
They need to lean into what already works for them.

â†³ Know your strengths.
â†³ Protect your energy.

7 Silent Habits Killing Your Mindset

(And exactly how to break them)

Most people don't believe they can achieve greatness.
Because they have limiting belief systems.

The truth about limiting beliefs?
They're built through these daily habits.

But you can break them.

Here are 7 Daily Habits Killing Your Mindset:

1/ The Comparison Trap
â†³ Scrolling social media for hours
â†³ Measuring your chapter 1 against someone's chapter 20

Break it by:
 Set a 30-min daily social media limit
 Document YOUR wins (no matter how small)

2/ The "When-Then" Loop
â†³ "When I have more money, then I'll invest"
â†³ "When I'm ready, then I'll start"

Break it by:
 Start with 1% action today
 Try. Fail. Try again.

3/ The Echo Chamber
â†³ Only following people who think like you
â†³ Avoiding constructive criticism

Break it by:
 Follow 5 people who challenge your views
 Ask for feedback from someone who succeeded where you struggled

4/ The Knowledge Hoarding
â†³ Endless learning, zero action
â†³ Using education as a shield from doing

Break it by:
 Implement 1 thing from each course before starting another
 Teach what you learn to someone else

5/ The Permission Seeking
â†³ Needing validation before every move
â†³ Letting others dictate your worth

Break it by:
 Make 1 decision daily without asking anyone
 Keep a "wins journal" of your good choices

6/ The Past Prison
â†³ Letting old failures define you
â†³ Carrying outdated stories

Break it by:
 Rewrite your failures as lessons
 Share your story to help others avoid the same pitfalls

7/ The Someday Syndrome
â†³ Pushing dreams to "later"
â†³ Making excuses instead of progress

Break it by:
 Break your big goal into daily tasks
 Do ONE thing toward your dream before noon daily

Here's the truth:
Your mindset is your foundation.
These habits are the cracks.

But now you have the tools to fix them.

Which action will you take in the next 24 hours?

Daniel Hickton, Esq.
Daniel Hickton, Esq.
postsData.content:
At the end of January, I had the honor of serving as a panelist at the Second Annual TechInLaw CLE Symposium, hosted by the University of South Carolina Joseph F. Rice School of Lawin the beautiful Karen J. Williams Courtroom.

It was an incredible experience to discuss the ethical use of AI, legal tech, and the associated cybersecurity/data privacy concerns alongside such esteemed industry leaders.

The event brought together over 150 attendees both online and in person, and Iâ€™m grateful for the opportunity to contribute to the conversation on how technology is reshaping the legal landscape.

A huge thank you our panel's moderatorfor leading an excellent panel discussion. It was a day of pure joy learning from and interacting with so many like-minded colleagues in this space such as,,,,,,,,,,,,,,, and.

I feel truly blessed and honored to have had the opportunity to share my experience leveraging AI technologies in my practice, while also delving into the very real data privacy and cybersecurity concerns surrounding the widespread use of large language models and natural language processing algorithms, such as ChatGPT.

Here are my key takeaways:
- When I first gave a CLE on ChatGPT in 2023, only 2 lawyers out of ~40 or so had heard of it or used it before...
- At this event, nearly every attendee had utilized ChatGPT in some capacity.
- "AI" is a buzz word and AI tools are increasingly entering a "snake oil sales" phase, with lawyers often being the target market.
- I think this is comparable to past trendy buzz words such as blockchain, social media, mobile technology, internet of things, bluetooth/WiFi: (why do we need WiFi refrigerators...)
-  It's crucial for legal professionals to understand the technology we adopt to avoid investing in costly tools that fail to meet expectations.
- As legal professionals, we have an ethical responsibility to ensure that we are competent in understanding the technologies that are now ubiquitous in the legal landscape.
- While some lawyers may be hesitant to embrace new technologies, many are eager to explore innovation.
- However, there remains a societal perception that lawyers are somewhat technologically behind.
- Asaptly pointed out, just as judges struggled to regulate the intersection of cars and railroads in their early days, the law will inevitably lag behind advancements in technology.

Iâ€™d also like to express my deepest gratitude to the entire USC Rice School of Law team in particularfor making the symposium such a successful and enriching event.

"From August 2024 to January 2025, we identified agentic AI systems using web searches, academic literature review, benchmark leaderboards, and additional resources that compile lists of agentic systems. For each of the 67 systems that met the criteria for inclusion in the index, we documented the systemâ€™s components, application domains, and risk management practices based on publicly available information and correspondence with developers. Both raw data and web versions of all 67 agent cards are available.

Agentic AI systems are being deployed at a steadily increasing rate. While some systems in the index were initially deployed in early 2023, approximately half of them were introduced in the second half of 2024. The majority of indexed agents specialize in software engineering and/or computer use.

We categorized the 67 agents into six groups: â€œsoftware,â€ â€œcomputer use,â€ â€œuniversal,â€ â€œresearch,â€ â€œrobotics,â€ and â€œother.â€ However, there is limited information regarding the risk management practices of developers of agentic systems, including their safety policies, internal testing, and external testing."

postsData.content:
Elon Musk's recent $97.4 billion bid to acquire OpenAI has ignited a significant debate regarding the future of artificial intelligence (AI) development and its governance. This unsolicited offer, led by Musk and supported by a consortium of investors, aims to take control of the nonprofit entity overseeing OpenAI. The proposal has been promptly rejected by OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, who humorously remarked about purchasing Twitter for a fraction of the price Musk paid.

Pros of Musk's Bid:

1. **Return to Open-Source Mission:** Musk's consortium proposes to realign OpenAI with its original open-source, safety-focused mission, potentially fostering greater transparency and collaboration in AI development.

2. **Diversification of AI Leadership:** Musk's involvement could introduce diverse perspectives into AI governance, potentially mitigating risks associated with monopolistic control by a single entity.

3. **Enhanced Innovation:** With Musk's track record in technological innovation, his leadership might accelerate advancements in AI, benefiting various sectors.

Cons of Musk's Bid:

1. **Potential for Centralized Control:** Consolidating control of OpenAI under Musk could lead to centralized decision-making, potentially limiting diverse input and oversight in AI development.

2. **Conflict of Interest:** Musk's existing ventures, such as xAI, may present conflicts of interest, raising concerns about prioritizing personal business interests over broader societal benefits.

3. **Disruption of Existing Partnerships:** OpenAI's collaborations with entities like Microsoft and Oracle could be jeopardized, potentially disrupting ongoing projects and partnerships.

**Implications for the Public and Government:**

- Public Access and Safety:The public's access to AI technologies and the safety of these systems could be influenced by Musk's leadership, depending on his commitment to ethical AI development.

-Regulatory Oversight: Government agencies may need to reassess regulatory frameworks to address the implications of such a significant shift in AI governance, ensuring that public interests are safeguarded.

In conclusion, while Musk's bid presents potential benefits in terms of innovation and realigning OpenAI with its foundational mission, it also raises concerns about centralized control, conflicts of interest, and the impact on existing partnerships. The ultimate outcome will depend on balancing these factors to ensure that AI development serves the broader public good.
postsData.commentAdded: Fascinating debate! Balancing innovation with ethical governance will be key. Lets see how this evolves for the future of AI!

55-year-old Technology Evangelist terminated after less than 2 years of employment. Increases severance by 4x or $62,500 from 1 month to 4 months plus healthcare. 

I consulted with an industry renown expert in her field named Bethany, who was brought into launch her specialty into the product lines of a large California technology company.

Everything went great the first year, receiving nothing but praise and acknowledgement.

 Asked to speak at industry and client events on behalf of the company
 Selected for a fast-track management program for key executives
 She received pay raise, bonus, and additional RSU grant

Everything changed when her boss left, and a new manager was assigned. Within a few months Bethany was...
 being actively managed out of the company
 targeted by her manager who wanted their friend to take over her role
 excluded from speaking engagements and industry conferences
 taken off projects that she was leading
 replaced by younger unqualified employees favored by their manager
 received a predatory performance review despite exceeding all goals
 only member of her team that did not receive a raise, bonus, or additional RSU grant, as she had received the prior year

It was shocking how Bethany was being treated given her stature in the industry and having received nothing but positive feedback throughout her tenure.

After having met with several attorneys, Bethany reached out to our service and signed up, favoring our approach to an attorney. She found our process to be extremely therapeutic.

Bethan did a fantastic job documenting her experience and putting together a moving and impactful document and counter to their severance offer.

Through 3 rounds of negotiations, she was able to increase her offer from 1 month to 4 months after less than 2 years of employment and was satisfied with it and moved on.

We were able to complete the process from signing up with us to a check in her bank in 9 weeks. She could not be more pleased and happier with her decision to work with us.

Not surprisingly, Bethany had several job offers within a few weeks once it was known she was on the market. As is often the case, good things come once you are freed from a bad situation.

postsData.content:
It doesnâ€™t matter what you teach them. It only matters what they learn.

Itâ€™s not about what you know or what you say.
Itâ€™s about what the other person actually takes away.

Are they engaged? Are they connecting the dots? Are they walking away with something valuable?

Or are they not so discretely slacking their coworker, "Bruh, this demo is rough."

Weâ€™ve all been there. And if youâ€™ve ever caught yourself in one of these traps, youâ€™re not alone.

So let's try not to:

- Feature Dump
Buyers donâ€™t remember lists of features. They remember how you can help them, not that your software has all these integrations most of which they don't care about and won't use.

- Talk Too Much
If the buyer isnâ€™t talking, theyâ€™re probably not learning. And if youâ€™ve been monologuing for 15 minutes straight, theyâ€™re definitely daydreaming about lunch.

- Surface level Disco
If your discovery call is just "Soâ€¦ what keeps you up at night?" (Please for the love of all things ... don't ask this!) youâ€™re getting surface-level answers. No real context = no real connection.

- Sell on Logic, Not Emotion
Yes, we all love our ROI calculators. No, they will not magically make the buyer care (sorry marketing). People donâ€™t buy because of efficiency metrics they buy because they feel like your solution is the right move for their needs.

- Focus on What You Know, Not What They Need to Learn
Your product knowledge is fascinating (go you for getting all your in house certifications!). But your buyer just wants to know: "How does this make my life easier?/How does this help me keep my job?"

- Leav No Clear Next Steps
"Letâ€™s circle back next week" is not a next step. Itâ€™s an invitation for your deal to disappear into the void.

Yes. Yes. Yes.

Leslie Venetz exactly! They how doesnâ€™t matter unless there is a strong WHY. 
Why they need it. Why it works.
This is gold. It's so true â€“ it's not about what we teach or say, it's about what the other person learns and takes away.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Focusing on the buyers needs and facilitating genuine engagement makes all the difference in truly effective communication.

postsData.name:
Nishant Kumar
Nishant Kumar
postsData.content:
Trust me 

You don't need to learn Data Modelling more than this for a Data Engineering role interview

 OLTP vs OLAP
â†³ OLTP (Online Transaction Processing) is used for handling real-time transactions, like banking or e-commerce. Itâ€™s optimized for speed and consistency.
â†³ OLAP (Online Analytical Processing) is used for reporting and analysis, like sales trends over time. It focuses on complex queries and aggregations.

 Star Schema vs Snowflake Schema
â†³ Star Schema has a simple structure with one central fact table and multiple dimension tables. It makes querying faster.
â†³ Snowflake Schema further normalizes data, reducing duplication but making queries slightly slower. Itâ€™s useful when storage optimization is important.

 Fact & Dimension Tables
â†³ Fact Tables store numerical data like sales, revenue, or order quantities.
â†³ Dimension Tables store descriptive details like customer names, product categories, or time details.
â†³ Slowly Changing Dimensions (SCDs) help track changes in data over time (e.g., updating customer addresses).

 Normalization & Denormalization
â†³ Normalization organizes data into multiple tables to remove duplication and maintain consistency (1NF, 2NF, 3NF).
â†³ Denormalization combines tables to reduce joins and speed up analytics queries, making it useful for OLAP systems.

 Indexing & Partitioning
â†³ Indexes help speed up search queries in databases, like an index in a book.
â†³ Partitioning breaks large datasets into smaller chunks, improving performance in big data systems.

 ETL vs ELT
â†³ ETL (Extract, Transform, Load): Data is cleaned and transformed before loading into the database. Used in traditional systems.
â†³ ELT (Extract, Load, Transform): Data is first loaded into a data warehouse, then transformed. This is common in cloud-based architectures.

The best way to master Data Modeling is by applying it in real-world projects.
